Strong schools are found in strong communities. You don’t find one without the other, which is why we want to take a moment and celebrate #FZCommunity. Since the pandemic began, we have received regular calls, emails and other messages from local non-profits, businesses and individuals asking how they can support teaching and learning in Fort Zumwalt. Countless donations of non-perishable food, hygiene products, masks and more have been dropped off to support our students in need. Just today First Assembly Church invited our director of Student Nutrition Services to accept a cash donation, which has cleared the negative lunch balances of students at 19 of our schools, allowing families to start the year fresh when they need breakfast or lunch.
Thank you to our community for your constant support of our teaching and learning. It’s this relationship that keeps us moving forward. #FORTifyZUMWALT

This morning a team from the Fort Zumwalt Educators Association sat down with a Board of Education team to discuss the proposed change in start date to Aug. 31, 2020, for the 2020-2021 school year.
The two teams came to an agreement and, pending final approval at the regular Board of Education meeting on Monday, Aug. 17, the first day of school has been delayed to Aug. 31. This delay created a few changes to the school year calendar. Most notably, while Winter Break will still be two weeks, students will return from Jan. 4. Spring Break is unchanged. The last day for students will be May 28, an Early Release day for students K - 8 and a half-day of finals for high school. The full calendar will be posted to our website once final Board approval is received.

Dear FZ Librarians,
Thank you for all you do as we mark National Library Workers Day! We know you are avid readers, and we know you are powerful coaches. You help students build the skills they need to navigate digital resources and create their own content. You spark student interests in STEM fields, podcasting, video storytelling and more. Last week you shared tips for successful video conferencing with #FZCommunity, helping us all be safer digital citizens
Even with all of these 21st Century lessons to teach, you always find time to remind us just how important reading is: it can take us where we want to go when we have to stay where we are.
We know how you miss your students, and we know they miss you, too. Sharing stories is one of our most powerful connections!
To learn more, tune in to a conversation with two of our librarians in this classic (2019) episode of the FORTiTUDE podcast: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iRTmukGt2R4&t=1995s
Have a great day!

Congratulations to seven Fort Zumwalt seniors for their outstanding academic accomplishments!

East High’s Maiya Woelbling and Nancy Lin, North High’s Roman Bishop and Daniel Blevins, South High’s Seungju Lee and West High’s Lauren Baetje and Sarvesh Palaniappan have been named to the Missouri Association of Secondary School Principals Missouri Scholars 100.

The selection is based primarily on a formula using the student’s grade point average and ACT or SAT score. Each student nominated had to first meet criteria of an “Academic Decathlon,” which included 10 “events” designed to assure the academic strength of the student. To meet the decathlon requirements, the student must have a minimum GPA of 3.750, a minimum ACT score of 29 or a minimum SAT score of 1,600, be ranked in the upper 10 percent of the class, and have taken upper level courses in mathematics, science, English, and foreign language. The student must also have excellent attendance, be an exemplary school citizen, and be involved in the school activity program.

Meet Sherron Gerard. For most people, the idea of working in a room full of 6-year-olds is hard to imagine, add to that teaching them math and it’s more than you can ask of most. But here, in Mrs.Gerard’s first grade classroom at JL Mudd Elementary, math is a brick-by-brick construction of the numeric system.
On their own, students work to express a larger number in its smaller parts: groups of tens, then ones. They stand when they are finished, then, once instructed, quietly circle to see how many other desks hold the same solution they found.
“When you have found four answers that match yours, come to the carpet,” Mrs. Gerard says. Once all are in place, Mrs. Gerard’s team of mathematicians works together, verifying the answer once more, and expressing it in several different forms. Problem solving. Collaboration. It’s all part of building leaders at JL Mudd Elementary. Fort Zumwalt School District: So All Reach Their Potential.

On their own, students work to express a larger number in its smaller parts: groups of tens, then ones. They stand when they are finished, then, once instructed, quietly circle to see how many other desks hold the same solution they found.
“When you have found four answers that match yours, come to the carpet,” Mrs. Gerard says. Once all are in place, Mrs. Gerard’s team of mathematicians works together, verifying the answer once more, and expressing it in several different forms. Problem solving. Collaboration. It’s all part of building leaders at JL Mudd Elementary. Fort Zumwalt School District: So All Reach Their Potential.

post_text: Welcome to Finance Friday, some insight into school finance. Did you know the district is required to undergo an independent financial audit each year? At the December Board of Education meeting, independent auditors from CliftonLarsonAllen presented the Board with their report. The auditor’s representatives reported that the district was given a clean opinion on all financial operations. A clean opinion means the school district is managing your tax dollars well and that there are no areas of concern. With the help of the district’s taxpayers, we have added technology teachers and instructional coaches, expanded our available technology and recruited and retained a high quality staff through competitive salaries and solid benefits. Through no-tax increase bond issues, we are able to maintain the 2.5 million square feet of space in our 27 schools, and add classrooms where growth is still affecting the district. And last year our graduates were offered $50 million in scholarship money, just one indication of a healthy instructional program supported by strong financial operations.

Welcome to Finance Friday, some insight on school finance. Did you know that school districts are required to maintain two separate revenue streams?

Operating Revenue is the money the district uses to operate every day. These revenues pay salaries and benefits, pay for supplies, equipment and educational materials such as books and technology. They also pay to keep the lights, heat or air conditioning and water on.

Bond Revenue can only be used to make capital improvements. These revenues can only be used to improve or maintain existing facilities (such as construction, renovation and repairs) or to construct or purchase a new facility.

The law requires money in either fund only be used for specific expenditures.

Thanks to voter approval of a $35 million no-tax-increase bond issue in April 2018, Fort Zumwalt completed several improvement projects this summer, ensuring safe, welcoming learning environments for our staff and students. Work continues at Flint Hill Elementary and North High to accommodate growing enrollment.

Recently we wrapped up Digital Wellness Week, an annual effort to help us all better understand the role of technology in our lives. Part of that was tips on determining best sources of online information.
On Oct. 29, Facebook will be removing all of the gray verification check marks like ours from its pages. These check marks help you recognize that this is an official page. How can you make sure you are keeping up with the real deal when the check mark is gone?
When it comes to Fort Zumwalt social media, remember you can always verify what's on our channels by going to our website. There you will find the district's Twitter feed, with a link, as well as a link to the district's Facebook page. If you encounter information that looks like a suspicious social media account or Fort Zumwalt impersonator, head to fz.k12.mo.us, click on the Twitter or Facebook logo and keep up with the real deal. And, when necessary, flag or report those impersonators to social media platform administrators. Together we're building a strong digital #FZCommunity.

Since the middle of the 2017-2018 school year, FZiAm, Fort Zumwalt School District's Diversity Program, has worked to provide a platform as an opportunity to not only have voices heard, but for people to be seen. With so many ways to share information, FZiAm now has a website where you can keep up with everything that is going on with the program in one place:

www.fziam.com

From videos, to professional development, and visits with students and staff throughout the district, the website is an opportunity for the community to experience the relationship building, difficult conversations, and story sharing as a result of the program.

We're extremely thankful to all those who have supported this program or shared their stories with us to spread the message that there is strength in our diversity.

#FZiAm
